metadata.title: Influence of nano-SiO2 on properties of fresh and hardened high performance concrete: A state-of-the-art review

Review
Influence of nano-SiO2 on properties of fresh and hardened high performance concrete: A state-of-the-art review
http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.conbuildmat.2017.05.059 0950-0618/ 2017 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
⇑ Corresponding author. E-mail address: pengzhang2014@yahoo.com (P. Zhang).
Peng Zhang a,⇑, Jinyi Wan a, Kejin Wang b, Qingfu Li a a School of Water Conservancy and Environment, Zhengzhou University, Zhengzhou 450001, China bDepartment of Civil, Construction and Environmental Engineering, Iowa State University, Ames, IA 50011, United States
h i g h l i g h t s
83 papers are reviewed on high performance concrete (HPC) containing nano-SiO2. Effect of nano-SiO2 on the fresh properties of HPC is discussed. The mechanical properties and durability of HPC are also addressed. Influence of nano-SiO2 on the microstructure of HPC is reviewed.
a r t i c l e i n f o
Article history: Received 6 March 2017 Received in revised form 1 May 2017 Accepted 6 May 2017
Keywords: High performance concrete Nano-SiO2 Fresh properties Mechanical properties Durability
a b s t r a c t
Application of nano-SiO2 (NS) particles to reinforce high performance concrete (HPC) has received widespread attention from both construction industry and researchers due to their interface improving effect, small size effect, filling effect and surface effect. This paper critically reviews previous research carried out on the effect of NS on properties of HPC. Detailed review on the fresh properties, mechanical properties and durability of high performance concrete containing NS particles are presented. Through 76 recent and past literatures, the influence of SiO2 nano-particles on workability and setting time of fresh mixture, compressive strength, flexural properties, fracture properties, water anti-permeability, chloride permeability, abrasion resistance, frost resistance, water absorption capacity, resistance to high temperatures and microstructure of HPC is discussed in this paper. The properties of NS modified concrete are compared with control concrete. Furthermore, this paper presents on the benefits and advantages to improve the HPC by using NS. It is shown that, in general, the incorporation of SiO2 nano-particles significantly improves the mechanical properties and durability of HPC though the flowability of the fresh concrete is decreased by the usage of NS. This literature review also aims to provide a comprehensive insight into possible application of NS modified concrete in the construction industry today.
2017 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
As the most consumable building material, concrete has been generally used in the world, which has high strength, high elasticity modulus, well plasticity and workability. The orientation of the modern civil engineering structures is high-rise, high strength and long design lifetime, which has higher requirements on concrete. However, the control concrete is difficult to meet these requirements. Compared with the control concrete, ultra high performance concrete (UHPC) and high performance concrete (HPC) have more excellent mechanical properties and durability, and the use of them in civil engineering is becoming more and more widely [1–5]. HPC can be illustrated as a kind of concrete that can meet especial combinations of properties and requirements of uniformity, which cannot usually be obtained routinely using traditional raw materials and conventional mixing, placing, and curing methods [6]. With the development of HPC, there are several preparation methods to get HPC. Commonly, some admixtures can be added in the concrete to obtain high performance, and the common admixtures include mineral admixtures, chemical admixture and fiber materials [7,8]. Among the mineral admixtures added to concrete, nano mineral materials become more and more popular.
The definition of nanometer came into being in the early 1980s, and nano-materials can be defined as the particles with the particle size between 1 nm and 100 nm. The nano-particle exists in the transition areas from the atom cluster to the macroscopic matter with a high specific surface ratio, which includes metal nanoparticle, nonmetal nano-particle, organic nano-particle, inorganic nano-particle and biology nano-particle [9]. Because of the ultra fine particle size of nano-particle, the surface electronic structure and crystal structure of the nano-particle change greatly so that some nanometer effects come into being, such as surface effect, small size effect, quantum effect and macroscopic quantum tunneling effect, which cannot be found for the macroscopic materials. Therefore, compared with the conventional granular materials, these superfine particles have a series of fantastic physical and chemical properties. As a kind of new materials, nano-material has already shown wide range of potential applications in the fields of national defense, electronic engineering, chemical industry, aerospace engineering, biology engineering and medical science based on its unique nanometer effects. The nano-particle has been regarded as a material which possesses great application prospect in the 21th century [10]. Because of the high specific surface ratio, the nano-particle with 4-nm diameter have more than 50% of its atoms at the surface and are thus very reactive [11]. The chemical reactions at the interface of the nano-particle and the agglomerates formed easily by the nano-particle have great influence on the behavior of the nano-materials. The free dispersed water in the mixture existing among the particles of cement, fly ash and nano-SiO2 (NS) will be decreased by the high specific surface ratio of the nano-particle. As a result, the addition of nano-particle into the concrete not only can greatly changed the properties of the fresh concrete, but also can improved the
mechanical and physical performance and microstructure of the hardened concrete [12]. There are many kinds of nano mineral materials can be used to enhance the concrete performance, such as nano-SiO2 [13], nano-CaCO3 [14], nano-Al2O3 [15], nano-Fe3O4 [16], nano-TiO2 [17], nano-TiO2 [18], nano-limestone [19], nanoflyash [20], and nano-metakaolin [21]. Among these nanomaterials, SiO2 nano-particle is the nano-particle with most extensive applications in concrete and HPC due to the high activity and extraordinary high specific area, because of which the pozzolanic activity in concrete can exhibit high level. Furthermore, NS can accelerate the dissolution of tricalcium silicate (C3S) and generation of calcium silicate hydrate (C-S-H) due to high activity, which
is in inverse proportion to the size of SiO2 particle, and NS can supply nucleation position for C-S-H [22].
The first research of nano-particles modified concrete can be traced to the study of Colston et al. [23], who studied the micro structure performance of the concrete containing zeolites and inorganic nano-particles by the methods of contour measurement, microelectronics scanning, X-ray fluorescence analysis and the microhardness and synchrotron radiation, and the results showed nano-particles have significant improvement on the microstructure of concrete. In China, Fu [24] gave a special speech upon the application of nano-particles in concrete on the 13th national conference of structural engineering held in 2004. For the first time, he discussed the improvement of silica fume and SiO2 nano-particles to the strength and durability of concrete and presented that NS and silica fume can be used to produce HPC. In recent years, with the deepening research of the materials modified by nanoparticles and the reduction in manufacturing costs of the nano-materials, the use of NS has received particular attraction to fabricate concrete and HPC in many structures with special functions. Many researchers have devoted themselves into the effect of nano-particles upon the concrete performance. The main goal of the present paper is to review most relevant developments with respect to the study of NS in concrete and HPC. The influence of SiO2 nano-particles on the properties of HPC including fresh performance, mechanical performance, durability properties and microstructure analysis are discussed in this paper.

sections.heading: 2. Effect of NS on fresh properties of HPC
2.1. Workability
sections.text:
Slump and slump flow are often used as appropriate parameters to evaluate the workability of HPC. Specifically, slump flow nicely evaluates the workability of the fresh concrete with high flowability. The state of aggregation of the primary SiO2 nano-particles can affect the final slump flow of the fresh concrete [25]. Supit and Shaikh [26] stated that the use of SiO2 nano-particles in common concrete observably reduced the slump by about 40% and 60% for NS content of 2% and 4%, respectively. Zhang et al. [27] investigated the effect of NS content on the slump flow and slump of the concrete incorporating 15% fly-ash. As can be seen from Fig. 1, the application of SiO2 nano-particles in the concrete mixtures caused losses of slump and slump flow, and these losses increased with increases in the nano-particles content. Also, Bahadori and Hosseini [28] showed through slump test that there is a severe slump loss for the concrete incorporating NS on condition that the ratio of super-plasticizers to cementitious materials keeps a constant.
Givi. et al. [29] observed through workability tests that SiO2 nano-particles content has significant influence on the fluidity of fresh concrete mixture with unchanged water-binder ration of 0.4, and all the concrete mixtures containing NS have low slump values and the workability cannot be acceptable. The low workability may be resulted by the increased powder surface area with nano-materials being used, which requires a large amount of water to have the cement and NS wetted. Hosseini et al. [30] showed that the working performance and fluidity of fresh recycled concrete was reduced greatly, however the cohesion of the fresh concretes was greatly increased by using SiO2 nano-particles, and the working performance loss grows with the increase of nano-particles content. Besides, the viscosity and yield stress of the fresh concrete also increases with the addition of NS [31]. Yu et al. [32] revealed that NS reduced the flowability of hybrid fibers (steel fibers and polypropylene fibers) reinforced HPC containing waste bottom ash. Li et al. [19] performed experiments to examine the effect of blended incorporation of SiO2 and CaCO3 nano-particles on the
flowability of the ultra HPC and showed that higher dosage of NS and nano-CaCO3 particles will lead to lower flowability. By measuring the time and slump diameter of slump flow test and V-funnel flow test, Jalal et al. [33] concluded that the blended concrete with SiO2 nano-particles and silica fume decreased the flowability characteristics of the fresh self compacting HPC, however the addition of silica fume and SiO2 nano-particles improved the consistency of the fresh concrete. Güneyisi et al. [34] studied the influence of NS on the workability of self-compacting lightweight aggregate concrete by carrying out the tests of T500 slump flow time and V-funnel flow time. The results indicate that both of the flow times will increase due to the use of SiO2 nano-particles, and the addition of SiO2 nano-particles can enhance the consistency of the self-compacting concrete produced by lightweight aggregate. It is suggested that the amount of water and water reducing agent should be adjusted for SiO2 nano-particles modified concrete to meet the requirements of workability of HPC.
Uniform dispersion of nano-particles in cement matrix is a key issue in applying nano-powders in cement composites. Many researchers have tried different methods to add nano-particles into concretes. Ji [35] dissolved the superplasticizer in water in advance, and then NS was added and stirred at a high speed for 2 min. After the cement, fine aggregates, coarse aggregates and fly ash were mixed in a rotary mixer for 30 s, the ready-mixed liq-
uid including water, superplasticizer and NS was poured into the rotary mixer. Finally, the concrete mixture was mixed for another 1.5 min. Li et al. [36] firstly mixed cement, sand and coarse aggregate at a low speed for 2 min in a concrete centrifugal blender. Then, nano-particles were added into the mixture of water reducing agent and water in a mortar mixer, and stirred at a high speed for 5 min. During the course of stirring, the defoamer was added. At last, the mixture of water, water reducing agent, nano-particles and defoamer was poured in the concrete centrifugal blender and stirred at a low speed for the final 2 min. In the study of Mohamed [37], the nano-particles, cement and silica fume were mixed at dry state using automatic mixer for 5 min to obtain the best dispersion for nano-particles, and then the aggregate was added to the water with admixture and mixed for 2 min. The uniform dispersion of nano-particles is caused by the high water demand of nanoparticles, which is the result of their high specific surface area. Among the above-mentioned mixing procedures, mixing nano-particles, cement and any other powder admixture at dry state in advance may be the best choice to obtain the best dispersion for nanoparticles [3].

sections.heading: 2.2. Setting time
sections.text: The setting time of HPC can be influenced greatly by the use of SiO2 nano-particles. Not only the initial but also the final setting time of the HPC decreases obviously due to the application of SiO2 nano-particles, and the setting time is lowered gradually by increasing the content of SiO2 nano-particles due to the faster hydration reaction speed in HPC containing nano-particles with respect to the control concrete [38]. The influence of SiO2 nanoparticles on the initial and final setting time of the concretes is illustrated in Fig. 2(a) and (b). Also, the addition of NS in various dosages can reduce the initial and final setting time, however the viscosity and yield stress of the fresh concrete increases [31]. Givi et al. [29] showed that the reduction of setting time of the samples with curing in lime solution is higher than those of the samples with curing in water for the concrete containing SiO2 nanoparticles. Zhang and Islam [39] also pointed out that there are remarkable reductions of the initial and final setting times for both concretes containing fly ash and slag, which were modified by 2% SiO2 nano-particles. The decrease in setting time with the addition of NS can take place due to ultra high specific surface area of NS particles. This means that the decrease in particles size leads to the higher surface energy [38]. This may be due to the fact that the smaller particle sizes lead to rapid increase in the surface area, allowing a fast rise in the number of atoms in the surface. These surface atoms are highly active and unstable, which result in a faster reaction speed.

sections.heading: 3. Effect of SiO2 nano-particles on mechanical performance of HPC
3.1. Compressive strength
sections.text:
Most studies indicate that the compression strength of the concrete can be improved by the application of SiO2 nano-particles to some degree. Salemi and Behfarnia [40] observed that the compression strength of the concrete was enhanced by 30% with the addition of 5% NS (by the weight of cementitious materials). Wang [41] also showed that the influence of 3–5% NS on the early compression strength is more significant than that on the later compression strength of HPC, especially when the curing period is 7 days. Said et al. [42] showed that the compressive strength of the concrete was increased with the incorporation of NS up to
6%, and especially, the compressive strength was obviously improved for concrete mixtures using 30% fly ash and NS. Supit and Shaikh [26] also showed that the early (3 days) compression strength of high volume fly-ash concrete incorporating 40% and 60% fly ash was improved because of addition of 2% NS. The study of Li [43] indicates that the adding of SiO2 nano-particles to highvolume fly ash concrete can lead to great growth not only in the long term strength but also in the short term strength because fly ash can be activated by NS particles. The early compression strength (3 days) of the concrete containing high volume (60%) fly ash can be improved by 95% because of use of 2% NS, however the other ages compressive strength exhibits no such great improvement [44]. The use of NS can improve the compression strength of the concrete incorporating fly ash at the curing period of 28 days and 91 days, however, NS will not enhance the strengths of the concrete containing slag at this two curing periods [39].
The dosage and size of SiO2 nano-particle has great influence on compressive strength of HPC. Zhang et al. [27] investigated the axial and cube compression strength of the concrete containing NS and fly ash. As is shown in Fig. 3, the cube compressive strength of 4 ages (3 days, 7 days, 28 days, 60 days) and the axial compressive of 28 days of the concrete increase with increased amount of SiO2 nano-particles being added when the dosage of SiO2 nanoparticles is less than 5%, however, the increase in both compressive
strengths is falling when the dosage of SiO2 nano-particles surpasses 5%. For different curing days, the cube compressive strength of HPC containing fly ash increases gradually with the increasing of NS dosage as the dosage is less than 5%, while there is a decreasing trend in the cube compressive strength when the NS content is more than 5% [45]. However, the optimum content of NS in pozzolan concrete is between 0.5% and 1% [46]. The compression strength of the concrete incorporating SiO2 particles with the mean particle size of 15 nm in early curing period is larger than that of the concrete incorporating NS with the mean particle size of 80 nm, however the final strength of specimens made with the concrete containing SiO2 particles with the mean particle size of 80 nm at 90 days curing period with moist curing was particularly increased [47]. Khaloo et al. [13] experimental investigated the effect of low replacement ratios of NS with various particle sizes on the compressive strength of HPC. It is revealed that the coarser NS particles at a small dosage (0.75%) exhibits preferable improvement in increasing compression strength of HPC than the SiO2 nano-particles with finer particle size. Gopinath et al. [48] carried out a series of experiments to investigate the influence of three types of suspended NS gel containing different amount of active NS with 99.99% pure SiO2 on the compressive strength of the concrete modified with nano-particles, and the results revealed that the concrete modified with 3% NS gel with the active nano content
of 40–41.5% has the maximum in compressive strength among the three types of NS gel used.
The observation of Givi et al. [29] indicates that the curing method of specimens also has different influence on the compression strength of SiO2 nano-particles binary blended concrete. For 7 days, 28 days and 90 days periods of curing, the compression strength of specimens being cured in the lime solution is smaller than that of the specimens being cured in water because there are more crystalline formed in the lime solution. Nik and Omran [49] evaluated the effect of NS on compression strength of different types of fibers reinforced HPC using ultrasonic pulse velocity method. Behfarnia and Salemi [50] observed that the compression strength of HPC containing SiO2 nano-particles is much larger than that of the HPC containing the same content of Al2O3 nanoparticles. Du et al. [51] showed that the improvement of NS particles on compressive strength of lightweight concrete at early stage (1 day, 7 days) is especially remarkable, while the benefits of NS might fade with longer curing periods. The compressive strength of recycled concrete can be developed by using NS with low content, which is less than 3% [30,52–54].

sections.heading: 3.2. Flexural properties
sections.text: Great improvement of flexural strength of concrete can be found by using SiO2 nano-particles and other nano-particles simultaneously. According to the study of Li et al. [55], the addition of NS can significantly increase the flexural fatigue properties of concretes and the theoretical fatigue lives of the concrete modified with NS can be increased in different extent. Givi et al. [29,47] also concluded that the flexural strength of SiO2 nano-particles binary blended concrete can be improved compared to the control concrete with SiO2 nano-particles reaching 1.0% replacement when the samples were being cured in water, however the compressive strength decreases while SiO2 nano-particles up to 2.0% replacement when the samples were being cured in lime solution. Li et al. [19] examined the influence of blended addition of SiO2 and CaCO3 nano-particles on the flexural strength of the ultra HPC, and found that, for the curing periods of 7 days and 28 days, the small dosage of NS and nano-CaCO3 increased the flexural strength of HPC and then the flexural strength began to reduce with the increasing of nano-particles dosage when the dosage surpassed the threshold. As is shown in Fig. 4, 1% is the threshold dosage of NS particles for flexural strength. However, Gopinath et al. [48] reported that the flexural strength of the concrete incorporating 3% NS is lower than the flexural strength of the control concrete. Amin and Abu el-hassan [56] also found that the inclusion of SiO2 and NiFe2O4 nano-particles increased the flexural strength of high strength concrete by about 23% compared to the control concrete. Furthermore, the addition of NS together with the hybrid fibers (polypropylene and steel fibers) into the concrete can significantly improve the flexural strength of HPC [32].

sections.heading: 3.3. Fracture properties
sections.text:
During the course of concrete setting there will inevitably appear microscopic cracks inside the concrete, which will develop and be connected each other to form some visible cracks because of the temperature and loading changes during operation. With the propagating of the cracks, fracture may occur for the concrete structures. As a result, it is necessary to enhance the fracture performance of concrete to prevent sudden breaking of the structures. There are many methods for obtaining fracture properties of the concrete, such as three-point bending test method [3], wedge splitting method [57], Brazilian disc method [58], single-edge notched semi-symmetric loading method [59], four-point shearing test method [60] and axial torsional testing method [61]. Among these
testing methods for obtaining fracture parameters of concrete, three-point bending test method is one of the most popular methods. During the course of fracture tests, many modern measuring methods are adopted such as fractography and non-destructive measuring methods [62]. Fan et al. [63] analyzed the objectivity of special test phenomena for both the crack propagation with deviation of notched concrete three-point bending beam and the
failure load reciprocating increase and decrease of the reinforced concrete three-point bending beam using the acoustic emission dynamic non-destructive detecting technology.
Zhang et al. [3,64] performed a series of three-point bending tests to reveal the influence of SiO2 nano-particles on fracture performance of HPC incorporating 15% fly ash as well as the notch sensitivity of HPC. The initial and unstable fracture toughness, and fracture energy of 28 days curing were taken as evaluation parameters of fracture of HPC. As shown in Fig. 5, the HPC modified with NS exhibits higher fracture parameters than the HPC containing no
SiO2 nano-particles. When the dosage of nano-particles is less than 5%, the fracture parameters increase gradually with increasing of dosage of SiO2 nano-particles, however the enhancement of these fracture parameters decrease with increasing of dosage of SiO2 nano-particles when the dosage of NS is more than 5%. From the variation rules in Fig. 5, it can be concluded that the use of lower dosage (less than 5%) of NS may be beneficial to enhance the fracture performance of HPC incorporating fly ash. From Fig. 6, it can be seen that the fracture parameters decrease step by step with the relative notch depth of the notched beam specimens increasing from 0.2 to 0.5, which illustrates that the fracture parameters of HPC containing NS are sensitive to the relative notch depth.

sections.heading: 4. Effect of NS on durability of HPC
4.1. Water anti-permeability
sections.text: High requirements of water anti-permeability of the concrete are necessary for many underwater structures, especially for the concrete structures dipping in the deep water for a long time. Ji [35] conducted water permeability experiments using the concrete permeability device to investigate the influence of NS on the antipermeability of concrete and reported that the anti-permeability of SiO2 nano-particles modified concrete is better than that of the control concrete. According to the findings of Du et al. [65], even the small dosage (0.3% and 0.9%) of NS can increase the water anti-permeability of concrete because this small dosage of SiO2 nano-particles can be uniformly dispersed. As is shown in Fig. 7, for the specimen curing periods of 28 days and 91 days, the water anti-permeability of the concrete modified with SiO2 nanoparticles is preferable than that of the control concrete without nano-particles whether the dosage of nano-particles is 0.3% or 0.9%. To evaluate NS on water permeability of concrete, Givi et al. [38] designed the water absorption coefficient, percentage and velocity experiments of concrete containing NS at 0.5, 1, 1.5, and 2 wt% of cement, and the results showed that NS improved the water anti-permeability of the binary-blended concrete, especially when 2 wt% of NS was used. The particle grading has considerable influence on the permeability performance of NS modified concrete. Based on the results of Givi et al. [66], the water antipermeability of the concrete containing NS with smaller particle size (80 nm) is better than that of the concrete containing NS with larger particle size (15 nm) after being cured with moist for 28 days.

sections.heading: 4.2. Chloride permeability
sections.text:
Adopting the test method of chloride rapid permeability, Zhang and Li [67] experimentally studied the anti-permeability to chloride of pavement HPC incorporating NS. The results indicate that the inclusion of NS improved the chloride anti-permeability of the concrete, and the improved degree is increasing with the decrease of NS content. Gopinath et al. [48] also showed that the chloride anti-permeability of NS coated concrete is much better than that of the control concretes. Du et al. [65] showed that the chloride anti-permeability of the concrete was dramatically improved by very small dosage (0.3%) of NS, and the chloride migration coefficient and diffusion coefficient of the specimen can be reduced by 28.7% and 31% respectively at this dosage of NS. Based on the results of the rapid chloride permeability test conducted by Said et al. [42], the addition of NS particles significantly decreased the physical penetration depths and passing charges of the concrete specimens as is shown in Fig. 8, and this indicate that the addition of small contents of SiO2 nano-particles possesses a remarkable effect on refining the pore structure and decreasing the conductivity of the concrete. Zhang and Islam [39] observed that 2% NS particles or silica fume can also decrease the charges passed through the concrete specimens containing fly ash or slag compared to the control concrete. The similar conclusion can be drawn by Supit and Shaikh [26] to the concrete containing large amounts of fly ash with the fly ash contents of 40% and 60%. From
the non-accelerated and accelerated chloride diffusion tests carried out by Du et al. [51], higher resistance to chloride penetration of the lightweight concrete was obtained by addition of SiO2 nanoparticles.

sections.heading: 4.3. Abrasion resistance
sections.text: There is a large quantity of high performance pavement concrete used in pavement structures each year. Besides strength, HPC for pavement still needs excellent abrasion resistance because the pavement structures endure cycling dynamical loads. Using the index of surface antiwear performance and index of side antiwear performance as evaluation parameters, Li et al. [36] investigated the abrasion resistance of concrete modified with NS in pavement using two indices of abrasion resistance, which are surface and side indices of abrasion resistance. As can be seen from Fig. 9, improvement in abrasion resistance to the pavement HPC modified with SiO2 nano-particles was observed compared with the common concrete and polypropylene fiber reinforced concrete.

sections.heading: 4.4. Frost resistance
sections.text:
In cold areas, freezing and thawing cycle is the main environmental factor that influences the durability of concrete. Taking some measures to improve the frost resistance of concretes has great significance for the mix proportion design of concrete. Applying quick-frozen method, Zhao et al. [68] investigated the influence of different volume dosages of SiO2 nano-particles on the frost resistance of concrete. The results showed that NS increased the number of impervious holes in hardened concrete, and the ability of freezing-thawing resistance of the concrete was improved by incorporating NS particles. As illustrated in Fig. 10, the compressive strength loss of the concrete specimens after 50, 150 and 300 freezing-thawing cycles decreases respectively with the inclusion of NS, and the concrete containing 5% nano-particles presents the lowest compressive strength loss [40]. The blending addition of NS and fiber materials has more significant improvement on the frost resistance of concrete than the single addition of NS. Salemi and Behfarnia [40] stated that the frost resistance of concrete was greatly enhanced by 83% by 5% NS (by the weight of cementitious materials), and the concrete will obtain the most excellent frost resistance if 0.2% polypropylene fiber (by the volume of concrete) is added again. However, the research findings of Behfarnia and Salemi [50] showed that the frost resistance of the concrete incorporating Al2O3 nano-particles is better than the concrete
incorporating the same dosage of SiO2 nano-particles though both of the two types of nano-particles can considerably improved the frost resistance of concrete.

sections.heading: 4.5. Water absorption capacity
sections.text: The experiment results of Supit and Shaikh [26] show that the water absorption rate of the control concrete at curing periods of 28 days and 90 days can be decreased by the addition of SiO2 nano-particles. From variation rules shown in Fig. 11, which were obtained by Bahadori and Hosseini [28], it can be concluded that there is a distinct decrease tendency for water absorption of the specimens (28 days) of the concrete with the same water to binder ratio and cement reduction when the dosage of NS particles increases from 1% to 3%. Najigivi et al. [69,70] performed experimental investigations to reveal the influence of SiO2 nano-particles on water absorption capacity of the ternary blended concrete mixed with rice husk ash adopting the water absorption coefficient, water absorption rate and water absorption percentage as the evaluation parameters of water absorption capacity. The results showed that the resistance of water absorption of the concrete in presence of rice husk ash was improved by the inclusion of NS particles at the curing periods of 7, 28 and 90 days, and the optimal blending of rice husk ash and NS to obtain the blended concrete with optimal resistance of water absorption is 20% of rice husk ash and 2% of SiO2 nano-particles (particle size of 80 nm). It was observed that the water absorption of lightweight concrete was continuously decreased with increasing dosage of NS addition at both initial and secondary absorption stage [51]. The results of Heidari and Tavakoli [46] also showed that the incorporation of SiO2 nano-particles significantly reduced the water absorption of the pozzolanic concrete, in which ground ceramic powder was added.

sections.heading: 4.6. Resistance to high temperatures
sections.text:
Bastami et al. [71] performed a series of tests to examine the resistance to elevated temperatures of the high strength concrete modified with NS. The mass loss, residual compression strength, residual tensile strength of the samples were measured at elevated temperatures of 400 C, 600 C and 800 C at the speed of 20 C/ min. Significant improvement of residual compression and tensile strength at elevated temperature was observed of the high strength concrete modified with NS compared with the control high strength concrete, while decreased mass losses of the samples were found with the presence of NS particles. Yang et al. [72] investigated the comparison of the shrinkage deformation, mass
change and strength change of the concrete containing different dosage of NS before and after undergoing different high temperature, and significant reduction of shrinkage deformation and mass change of the concrete after high temperature was found with the incorporation of SiO2 nano-particles. The curve variation in Fig. 12 indicates that the inclusion of different content of SiO2 nanoparticles greatly enhance the compression strength of the concrete undergoing different high temperature, and 5% content of nanoparticle has greatest contribution. Based on the results of a series of uniaxial compression experiments of steel fiber and NS particle modified concrete after exposure to high temperature (25–800 C), Gao and Li [73,74] established a simple mathematical model of stress-strain relationship of the composite concrete considering the effect of NS dosage, steel dosages and undergoing temperature. Yan and Xing [75,76] revealed the effect of NS on the mechanical and microstructure of the concrete reinforced by steel fibers after undergoing different high temperatures, and concluded that the structure of the interfacial transition zone inside the concrete can be significantly improved by NS particles, and the interface bonding strength between the steel fiber and the matrix was enhanced because of the mixing of NS.

sections.heading: 5. Effect of NS on microstructure of HPC
sections.text:
With the inclusion of SiO2 nano particles, the microscope properties of the concrete can be improved by the interface improving effect, small size effect, filling effect and surface effect of nanoparticles [41], and the microstructure of concrete can be improved by the SiO2 nano-particles acting as an activator, which meanwhile promotes the hydration process inside concrete [22,77–79]. Through the thermal and microstructural analysis, Said et al. [42] observed that the content of NS greatly influenced the filler and pozzolanic effect, by which the nano-particles can improve the pore structure of the concrete containing NS. The nucleation effect of SiO2 nano-particles can promote the hydration of cement and form large amounts of C-S-H gel [80]. Through ESEM test, Ji [35] reported that the concrete modified by SiO2 nano-particles exhibits more compact and uniform micro-structure than the concrete containing no nano-particles. The concrete modified with NS possessed more compact and uniform microstructure because the Ca (OH)2 crystals could be absorbed by NS, and thus the interfacial transition zone (ITZ) of the cementitious matrix and the aggregates became denser due to the reduction of the quantity and the size of Ca(OH)2 crystals [38,37]. Givi et al. [29] also showed that the filler
effect was improved by NS particles and more C-S-H gel was formed due to the ultra high pozzolanic activity of nano-particles when the concrete specimens were cured in lime solution. Zhang and Islam [39] showed that the modifications of SiO2 nanoparticles to the micro-structure of the concrete may be due to that the existence of SiO2 nano-particles decreases the porosity inside the cement paste and in ITZ of the aggregates and the cementitious matrix, which can be attributed to a series of physical and chemical effects. Du et al. [65] showed that the concrete containing NS obtained less porous and more homogeneous microstructure in ITZ because of the pozzolanic reaction and filler effect of SiO2 nano-particles. Su et al. [81] also stated that the contribution of SiO2 nano-particles to the dynamic strength of ultra HPC included the pozzolanic effect and filling effect.
Using the microstructural tests of scanning electron microscopy (SEM), X-ray diffraction and mercury intrusion porosimetry, Khaloo et al. [13] conducted the microstructure investigation of HPC containing different particle size of NS. The results indicate that the coarser pyrogenic NS exhibits lower pozzolanic reactivity and smaller acceleration of cement hydration than the finer nanoparticles. Moreover, the NS with coarser pyrogenic v has better contribution to HPC matrix due to the development of the denser and more compacted microstructure because the coarser particle of NS can prevent larger and more agglomerates of nanoparticles. Givi et al. [47] showed that there was more generation of C-S-H gel around SiO2 nano-particles with the particle size of 15 nm at the early stage curing of the concrete compared to that around NS with the particle size of 80 nm. Based on the Backscattered electron (BSE) images analysis and X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis, Shaikh and Sarker [44] stated that the microstructure of the concrete containing a large amount of fly ash and 2% NS was obviously improved. The study of Supivt and Shaikh [26] indicates that NS can react more rapidly with the free lime in the course of hydration reaction than fly ash, and more secondary C-S-H gel can be produced to fill into the micro-voids due to the fairly tiny particle size and large specific surface area of SiO2 nano-particles in high volume fly ash concrete. Through backscattered-mode SEM analysis and test of Vickers microhardness, Mukharjee and Barai [52] investigated the characterizations of ITZ of recycled aggregate concrete (RAC) incorporating NS, and found that the porosity of ITZ of RAC was decreased by the inclusion of NS because of the voids filling effect of SiO2 nano-particles. The investigation of Zhao and Huo [82,83] also concludes that SiO2 nano-particles observably improved the microstructure of rubber-recycled concrete.

sections.heading: 6. Conclusions
sections.text:
The influence of SiO2 nano-particles on the fresh performance, mechanical performance and durability of high performance concrete was reviewed through 76 recent and past literatures. The workability and setting time of fresh mixture, compressive strength, flexural properties, fracture properties, water antipermeability, chloride permeability, abrasion resistance, frost resistance, water absorption capacity, resistance to high temperatures and micro-structure of the concrete modified with SiO2 nano-particles were discussed. The performance of NS modified concrete was contrasted with control concrete. On the basis of the review, the main conclusions can be drawn as follows:
(1) From the literature review, it can be revealed that the addition of NS in HPC reduces the slump flow and slump. Greater cement replacement amounts achieve lower workability. In this case, it is suggested that appropriate amounts of water reducing agent should be used to ensure the workability of the fresh HPC containing NS.
(2) The setting time of HPC can be influenced greatly by the use of SiO2 nano-particles. Not only the initial but also the final setting time of the HPC decreases obviously with the inclusion of NS, and the setting time is lowered gradually by increasing the content of SiO2 nano-particles. (3) Use of NS for cement replacement in HPC enhances the concrete compressive strength. The greater the amount of NS is used, the higher compressive strength the concrete exhibits, when the dosage of SiO2 nano-particles is less than 5%. The type, dosage and size of SiO2 nano-particle have great effect on compressive strength of HPC. (4) Inclusionof SiO2 nano-particles enhances the flexural strength and flexural fatigue performance of HPC. The small dosage of NS can enhance the flexural strength of HPC and the flexural strength begins to decline with increasing of nano-particles dosage when the dosage surpasses the threshold. (5) When the dosage of nano-particles is less than 5%, the fracture parameters increase gradually as the amount of SiO2 nano-particles increases, however the enhancement of these fracture parameters decrease as the amount of SiO2 nanoparticles increases with the dosage of nano-particles below 5%. The fracture parameters of HPC containing NS are sensitive to the relative notch depth. (6) Incorporation of SiO2 nano-particles (even the small dosage of 0.3% and 0.9%) improves the water anti-permeability of the binary-blended concrete, especially when 2 wt% of NS is used. The particle grading has considerable influence on the permeability performance of SiO2 nano-particles hybrid concrete, and the improvement of nano-particle with smaller particle size (80 nm) is better than that with the larger particle size (15 nm). (7) NS modified HPC showed higher chloride anti-permeability compared to the common concrete. The chloride migration coefficient and diffusion coefficient of the specimen can be reduced by 28.7% and 31% respectively with the inclusion of SiO2 nano-particles at the dosage of 0.3%. (8) Great improvement in abrasion resistance for the pavement HPC containing NS was observed compared with the control concrete and polypropylene fiber reinforced concrete. (9) SiO2 nano-particles can increase the number of impervious holes in hardened concrete, and the ability of frost resistance of the concrete can be enhanced by incorporating NS particles. The compression strength loss of the concrete samples undergoing 50, 150 and 300 freezing-thawing cycles decreases respectively due to the inclusion of SiO2 nanoparticles, and the concrete containing 5% nano-particles presents the lowest compressive strength loss. (10) MixingNS in concrete remarkablydecreases thewater absorption capacity of HPC. There is a distinct reduction tendency in water absorption for the specimens (28 days) of the concrete with the same water to binder ratio and cement reduction when the dosage of NS particles increases from 1% to 3%. (11) Significant improvement of residual compression and tensile strength at elevated temperature was observed of the high strengthconcretemodifiedwithNScomparedwith the control high strength concrete, while decreasedmass loss of the specimens was found with the existence of SiO2 nano-particles. (12) With the addition of SiO2 nano-particles, the microscope properties of concrete can be improved by special effects of nano-particles. SiO2 nano-particles can promote the hydration of cement and generate a large amount of C-S-H gel, and the nano-particles decrease the porosity inside the cement paste and in ITZ between the aggregates and the cementitions matrix.

referenceMentions.context: Effect of NS content on slump and slump flow [27].
nano-particle and biology nano-particle [9].
The nano-particle has been regarded as a material which possesses great application prospect in the 21th century [10].
Because of the high specific surface ratio, the nano-particle with 4-nm diameter have more than 50% of its atoms at the surface and are thus very reactive [11].

As a result, the addition of nano-particle into the concrete not only can greatly changed the properties of the fresh concrete, but also can improved the mechanical and physical performance and microstructure of the hardened concrete [12].

There are many kinds of nano mineral materials can be used to enhance the concrete performance, such as nano-SiO2 [13], nano-CaCO3 [14], nano-Al2O3 [15], nano-Fe3O4 [16], nano-TiO2 [17], nano-TiO2 [18], nano-limestone [19], nanoflyash [20], and nano-metakaolin [21].

Through ESEM test, Ji [35] reported that the concrete modified by SiO2 nano-particles exhibits more compact and uniform micro-structure than the concrete containing no nano-particles.

The concrete modified with NS possessed more compact and uniform microstructure because the Ca (OH)2 crystals could be absorbed by NS, and thus the interfacial transition zone (ITZ) of the cementitious matrix and the aggregates became denser due to the reduction of the quantity and the size of Ca(OH)2 crystals [38,37].

metadata.abstractText: Application of nano-SiO2 (NS) particles to reinforce high performance concrete (HPC) has received widespread attention from both construction industry and researchers due to their interface improving effect, small size effect, filling effect and surface effect. This paper critically reviews previous research carried out on the effect of NS on properties of HPC. Detailed review on the fresh properties, mechanical properties and durability of high performance concrete containing NS particles are presented. Through 76 recent and past literatures, the influence of SiO2 nano-particles on workability and setting time of fresh mixture, compressive strength, flexural properties, fracture properties, water anti-permeability, chloride permeability, abrasion resistance, frost resistance, water absorption capacity, resistance to high temperatures and microstructure of HPC is discussed in this paper. The properties of NS modified concrete are compared with control concrete. Furthermore, this paper presents on the benefits and advantages to improve the HPC by using NS. It is shown that, in general, the incorporation of SiO2 nano-particles significantly improves the mechanical properties and durability of HPC though the flowability of the fresh concrete is decreased by the usage of NS. This literature review also aims to provide a comprehensive insight into possible application of NS modified concrete in the construction industry today. 2017 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
